figure.note: Pencil drawing: gateWG has here copied part of David Roberts's illustration in Thomas Roscoe, The Tourist in Spain. Granada (London, 1835), pp. 172-3: 'Tower of the Seven Vaults'.
figure.label: Puerta de siete SuelosGate of the Seven Floors (or Vaults, in Roberts's caption), Alhambra, Granada. Blown up by the French in 1812, soon after WG's visit, and rebuilt in the twentieth century from illlustrations.

div.ab: By this gate King went to deliver keys to Kg of Spain. went over hill of Los Martires and garden of present Convent. Then into ravine by Xenil to mosk now Hermitage of St Sebastian. Here is the record in the wall. Then went to his family across the Vega by hill of Tears so to that called the Moors last sigh.Very similar to [Irving], Alhambra, vol. 1, pp. 170-2. Although WG may have taken the same route as Irving, who traces that of Boabdil [Muhammad XII of Granada], WG's observations here match Irving's exactly, with a couple of variations in spelling: WG changes 'Los Martyros' to 'Los Martires' and 'mosque' to 'mosk'. WG is probably drawing on a close paraphrasing of Irving's passage, with the same spelling of 'Los Martires', in Roscoe, Tourist in Spain. Granada, pp. 173-5.
